an6.41:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
an6.41:4.3: And then Venerable Sāriputta got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, descended the Vulture’s Peak together with several mendicants. At a certain spot he saw a large tree trunk.
an6.41:4.5: “Reverends, do you see this large tree trunk?”
an6.41:5.1: “If they wanted to, a mendicant with psychic powers who has mastered their mind could determine this tree trunk to be nothing but earth.
an6.41:5.3: Because the earth element exists in the tree trunk. Relying on that a mendicant with psychic powers could determine it to be nothing but earth.
an6.41:5.4: If they wanted to, a mendicant with psychic powers who has mastered their mind could determine this tree trunk to be nothing but water. …
an6.41:5.5: Or they could determine it to be nothing but fire …
an6.41:5.6: Or they could determine it to be nothing but air …
an6.41:5.7: Or they could determine it to be nothing but beautiful …
an6.41:5.8: Or they could determine it to be nothing but ugly.
an6.41:5.10: Because the element of ugliness exists in the tree trunk. Relying on that a mendicant with psychic powers could determine it to be nothing but earth.”
